column52: Very Practical
column53: Business Intelligence as a major should be selected in 3rd year, allowing 2 years of learning. At some point the depth of the topics and the fast moving nature of a semester made this feel like a crash course. Most of the interest points can be explored after the course, however if the 8 topics were spread all through allowing us to fully immerse ourselves into the content, we would be industry ready by the end of our 4th year - positioning us strategically.

column50: I think that neural networks should be a topic on its own to be explored more in-depth.
column52: The course is very well structured and follows a logical flow from the BI 1 and BI 2. All steps outlined in KDD are covered throughout the course, and I have learnt a lot about data pipeline, pre-processing, training and deploying models. I think that every topic was explained in-depth, which helped me gain understanding about concepts that I would not have been able to achieve if I worked independently. I also enjoyed the lab tasks as they helped me understand the concepts more practically and enhanced the way I approached different problems. The lecturer is also very organised, in terms of both notes and assigning coursework, and knowledgeable, which I think enhanced the learning experience overall.
column53: In my opinion, more labs should be assigned to individuals (or slightly smaller groups) if possible. I think this will help learners in future classes be a little more independent and learn more from the labs.
column60: The course is very well structured and follows a logical flow from the BI 1 and BI 2. I think that every topic was explained in-depth, which helped me gain understanding about concepts that I would not have been able to achieve if I worked independently. I also enjoyed the lab tasks as they helped me understand the concepts more practically and enhanced the way I approached different problems. The lecturer is also very organised, in terms of both notes and assigning coursework, and knowledgeable, which I think enhanced the learning experience overall. column2: I CONSENT to my feedback being analyzed and used for educational and research purposes, provided that all data is fully anonymized.
column50:
In my opinion, the Business Intelligence I and II curriculum could be enhanced by including more practical and emerging topics that reflect current trends in data-driven decision-making. For example:

Data Visualization and Storytelling Tools – Hands-on training with tools like Power BI, Tableau, or Looker to help students communicate insights effectively.

Big Data Analytics – Understanding how to process and analyze large-scale datasets using modern platforms like Hadoop or Spark.

Machine Learning for Business Insights – Introducing predictive analytics, classification models, and AI integration for real-world business forecasting.

Cloud-Based BI Solutions – Exposure to BI tools on AWS, Google Cloud, or Azure to understand how organizations are migrating analytics to the cloud.

Data Governance and Ethics – Discussing data privacy, compliance (e.g., GDPR), and responsible use of business data.
column51: In my opinion, some of the basic theoretical or overly introductory topics could be reduced or removed from the Business Intelligence I and II curriculum to make room for more practical, hands-on learning. For example, the extended coverage of traditional database concepts (like basic SQL operations or data warehousing theory) could be shortened, since these are usually covered in earlier courses.
column52:
1.I liked how the course combined both theoretical and practical aspects of Business Intelligence, allowing me to understand concepts and then apply them in real-world scenarios.

2.The lecturer’s clarity and engagement made complex topics easier to grasp, and the use of practical exercises and class discussions helped reinforce understanding.
column53: 1.I recommend including more hands-on projects and case studies using real datasets and BI tools. This would help students better understand how Business Intelligence is applied in real business environments and strengthen their practical skills.
column60:
1.I liked how the course combined both theoretical and practical aspects of Business Intelligence, allowing me to understand concepts and then apply them in real-world scenarios.

2.The lecturer’s clarity and engagement made complex topics easier to grasp, and the use of practical exercises and class discussions helped reinforce understanding. 1.I recommend including more hands-on projects and case studies using real datasets and BI tools. This would help students better understand how Business Intelligence is applied in real business environments and strengthen their practical skills.

column52:
1. Practical Application of Concepts: I liked that the course didn’t just focus on theory but also emphasized hands-on learning. Using real-world datasets and BI tools allowed me to see how concepts like data visualization, dashboards, and reporting apply directly to business decision-making.
2.Interactive Learning Environment: I appreciated how the teaching encouraged interaction through discussions, case studies, and group projects. This approach helped me understand complex topics like data analytics, predictive modeling, and KPIs more effectively because I could learn from both the lecturer and my peers.
